text: there are many different ways to predict
how a relationship might go people are
so varied and the way different
disorders can affect our relationships
can be just as varied as how they meet
each other one pairing is particularly
fascinating and how perfect or rather
perfectly destructive it is we're
talking about the relationship between
narcissists and people with borderline
personality disorder we don't want to
reduce anyone as an individual to the
disorder they happen to struggle with
these are the findings of many
well-informed people in the field of
psychology and specifically personality
disorders there are differences between
narcissists as narcissism is a spectrum
from grandiosity to self-importance to
vulnerability similarly not all
individuals with borderline personality
are the same but when these two
particular disorders crash into one
another we can see a truly unique and
tragic relationship unfold narcissistic
personality disorder affects how people
see themselves they feel entitled they
can't take criticism and they don't care
about other people's emotions ions
borderline personality disorder affects
moods and behaviors it can make you feel
emotionally unstable and insecure and it
can make you feel worthless in many ways
these disorders have the opposite effect
on the people who suffer from them this
pairing is a perfect storm of issues the
general timeline is fairly predictable
as they begin to date they idealize each
other this is a feature of both
narcissism and BPD their interest in
each other boils over into a
relationship but a new issue starts to
reveal itself BPD typically comes with
abandonment anxiety this makes them
easily exploitable by The Narcissist who
will eventually want to push them away
however relationships can be chaotic and
overwhelming for people suffering from
BPD they'll also typically have
engulfment anxiety so they split that
should be the end but these
relationships have a way of repeating
and going on and off shared features
both BPD and narcissism can be grandiose
in other words they can both be boastful
and carry an inflated ego they also both
have a false self in BPD the false self
is usually the version of them that has
regulated emotions and is fairly
sociable disguising their turbulent
inner self for the narcissist their
false self is the Flawless a inspiring
person that they believe they should be
perceived as they both have complicated
ways of feeling attachment narcissists
can feel emotions but they can't feel
attachment to someone as an individual
they can attach to inanimate objects
which often means that their attachment
to people isn't based on emotion but
rather on objectification
The Narcissist might prize the body of
their partner or the things their
partner can do for them people with BPD
get attached to regulations they are
overwhelmed by their emotions so having
someone who can regulate their emotions
and behaviors is valuable and sometimes
necessary for them they love the
regulated state that a narcissist can
provide for them not the regulator while
they may love their partner in a way
that the narcissist cannot they are
still attached to what the narcissist
provides more than the narcissist
themselves this creates dependencies
narcissist ists need to maintain a
grandio self view someone who idealizes
them can offer that their partner is
like a well of validation that they can
reliably turn to maintain their sense of
grandiosity even if that means they have
to devalue their partner on the other
hand their partner with BPD sees someone
who is seemingly extremely in control of
their emotions the belittling and
devaluing that the narcissist inflicts
makes the person with BPD fear that they
will lose their emotional guide but it
doesn't matter right if it works it
works that's the problem if doesn't work
the combination is volatile and bound to
force them both to repeat their traumas
make no mistake it is toxic and
unhelpful and healthy behavior when the
person with BPD decides to leave it
absolutely shatters the narcissist's ego
and sense of control and dominance only
for them to start the cycle all over
again even though they fight and create
constant uncomfortable tension they
can't leave each other they become
addicted to what the other provides the
narcissist is allowed to bring their
partner up and break them down over and
over again while the borderline can love
themselves through the way the
narcissist builds them up while being
able to break away when they become
overwhelmed this isn't healthy as
neither gets to face their deeper
problems they are essentially reliving
and inflicting their trauma on their
partner these are some of the most
destructive andh helpful relationships
that a person can fall into the danger
is clearly pointed out by psychologist
Sebastian bochard and colleagues who
found low relationship satisfaction in
relationships between BPD and
personality disorder as well as higher
attachment and security poorer
communication and higher rates of
violence narcissists also tend to
devalue their Partners while also
feeling like a rival to them this
relationship is both extremely
destructive and extremely magnetic for
both the people involved even if they do
break up they are likely to get back
together and repeat the relationship
over and over again even if you aren't a
narcissist or someone with borderline
personality disorder it's important to
be mindful of how you and your partner
fit together no one should subject
themselves to emotional tormenters
because they think it is better than the
alternative of being alone if you
